review.title: Towards Accurate Word Segmentation for Chinese Patents
review.abstract: A patent is a property right for an invention granted by the government to the inventor. An invention is a solution to a specific technological problem. So patents often have a high concentration of scientific and technical terms that are rare in everyday language. The Chinese word segmentation model trained on currently available everyday language data sets performs poorly because it cannot effectively recognize these scientific and technical terms. In this paper we describe a pragmatic approach to Chinese word segmentation on patents where we train a character-based semi-supervised sequence labeling model by extracting features from a manually segmented corpus of 142 patents, enhanced with information extracted from the Chinese TreeBank. Experiments show that the accuracy of our model reached 95.08% (F1 score) on a held-out test set and 96.59% on development set, compared with an F1 score of 91.48% on development set if the model is trained on the Chinese TreeBank. We also experimented with some existing domain adaptation techniques, the results show that the amount of target domain data and the selected features impact the performance of the domain adaptation techniques.

sections.heading: Experiments
sections.text: In this section, we will present our experimental results. We will first describe the datasets we used for our experiments, and then present experimental results showing that the features we proposed for the patent datasets are effective. Finally, we will present domain adaptation experiments that show that the effectiveness of domain adaptation techniques is linked to both the size of the target training and the features used, suggesting that there are limitations to these domain adaptation techniques and that they cannot be adopted blindly.

sections.heading: Data sets
sections.text: The Chinese TreeBank is a word that is segmented, POS tagged and syntactically bracketed corpus and it is widely used in the NLP community to learn word segmentation, POS tagging and syntactical parsing systems. This version of the Chinese TreeBank consists of 2,448 text files, 51,447 sentences, 1,196,329 words and 1,931,381 Hanzi (Chinese characters). This data set has a variety of different sources including Xinhua news wire, news articles, transcribed news broadcasts and weblog articles. However, none of these data sources is of a technical nature. We use the word segmentation and POS tags annotation in this data set and do not make use of its syntactic structures in our experiments.

sections.heading: Related work
sections.text: Most of the work to date on Chinese word segmentation has focused on messaging wire, and a widely used technique is character-based representation, combined with sequential learning models such as Maximum Entropy Markov models (Xue 2003; Low et al. 2005) and Conditional Random Field (Zhao et al. 2006; Sun and Xu 2011; Zeng et al. 2013b; Zhang et al. 2013b; Wang et al. 2013a). More recently, word-based models using perceptron learning techniques (Zhang et al. 2007) have also yielded very competitive results. There have also been some successful attempts to combine character-based and word-based techniques (So 2010; Zeng et al. 2013a). The method of deep learning also refers to the abandonment of word segmentation in Chinese (Zheng et al. 2013; Pei et al. 2014). As Chinese word segmentation has shifted to a very high level of accuracy of word segmentation in the news field, attention has shifted to the wireless field.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we presented a precise character-based word segmentation model for Chinese patents. We show that word segmentation models trained on currently available datasets do not work well for patents. We then took a pragmatic approach, first annotating a significant amount of patent data manually, and then designing features to capture the distribution characteristics of scientific and technical terms in patents. We are able to achieve an accuracy of over 95.08% F1 values on the test set and 96.59% on the development set, compared to 88.88% F1 values on the test set and 91.48% on the development set when the model is trained on the Chinese TreeBank. Our first contribution is to comment on a significant amount of Chinese patent data that we intend to make publicly available, and this will help other researchers further improve word segmentation accuracy on Chinese patents.
